unit_designation: 1re Brigade Française Libre (1st Free French Brigade)

commander.name: Général de Brigade Marie-Pierre Koenig
commander.previous_service: Commanded Free French forces in Syria Campaign (June-July 1941). Promoted to Général de Brigade December 1941. Led 1st Light Free French Division reorganization into Brigade Group.
commander.notes: Distinguished officer who would lead the famous defense of Bir Hakeim (May-June 1942). Later promoted to Général de Division and commanded French Forces of the Interior (FFI) in 1944.

3.notes: French rifles still in use, being replaced by British equipment

Ambulance.notes: British-supplied. Notable: Susan Travers served as ambulance driver.

Canon de 75 modèle 1897.notes: French WWI-era field gun, limited ammunition supply

supply_logistics.supply_status: Free French Brigade reorganized from 1st Light Free French Division in December 1941 to adapt to British military organization. Deployed to Western Desert under British Eighth Army command. Moved to Bir Hakeim position mid-February 1942 (45 miles inland from Mediterranean, southwest of Tobruk). Supplied entirely by British logistics (food, ammunition, water, fuel). Lacks heavy equipment and tanks. Ammunition supply for French weapons (MAS-36 rifles, Canon de 75mm, 47mm AT guns) limited. Transition to British equipment ongoing during Q1. Water critical constraint at isolated Bir Hakeim position.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Rocky desert, isolated position at Bir Hakeim (ancient well site)

subordinate_units.notes: Two Foreign Legion battalions. Elite unit, veterans of Syrian Campaign. Core of brigade combat power. Would become famous at Bir Hakeim defense (May-June 1942).
Marines from French Pacific territories (Tahiti, New Caledonia). Volunteers who joined Free French after fall of France.
Colonial troops from Ubangi-Shari (modern Central African Republic). Part of Free French African forces.
Marine Infantry Battalion. Mix of Free French volunteers.
North African company (likely Algerian, Moroccan, Tunisian volunteers)
Company of sappers for minefields, fortifications, demolitions
One artillery battalion with British 25-pounders and French 75mm guns
Company of anti-tank gunners with British 2-pounders and French 47mm AT guns. Would knock out 32 tanks at Bir Hakeim battle (May-June 1942).
Medical detail including ambulance drivers (Susan Travers served here, later admitted to Foreign Legion)
Brigade headquarters, signals, supply, transport elements
Armored car detachment with British-supplied vehicles for reconnaissance and screening

tactical_doctrine.role: Free French brigade under British Eighth Army command. Assigned to anchor southern flank of Gazala Line at isolated Bir Hakeim position (from mid-February 1942). Infantry brigade without tanks, relying on defensive positions, minefields, and anti-tank guns. Mission: Hold Bir Hakeim to prevent Axis flanking maneuver around southern end of British defensive line.
special_capabilities: Foreign Legion elite infantry (13e DBLE - highly motivated, experienced veterans)
Multinational composition (French metropolitans, Foreign Legion, Pacific Marines, African colonials)
Desert operations experience from Syrian Campaign (June-July 1941)
tactical_innovations: Integration into British logistics and command structure
Transition from French to British equipment during Q1 1942
Isolated defensive 'box' position at Bir Hakeim (self-contained fortress in desert)
Combined Free French forces (Legion, Marines, Colonials) under single command
known_issues: Lacks tanks and heavy equipment (brigade designated 'lacking tanks and much heavy equipment')
Mixed French and British equipment causing logistics challenges
Limited ammunition for French weapons (MAS-36, 75mm guns, 47mm AT guns)
Isolated position at Bir Hakeim (45 miles inland, vulnerable to encirclement)
Water supply constraint in desert (dependent on wells at Bir Hakeim)
Transition period: reorganizing from division to brigade, adapting to British organization
Limited artillery compared to British brigades (only 16 guns vs typical 24-48)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Experience from Syrian desert campaign 1941. Water discipline critical. Navigation by sun compass and dead reckoning. Camouflage and concealment against air reconnaissance. Defensive fortification techniques adapted to rocky desert terrain at Bir Hakeim.

scenario_suitability: Reconnaissance and patrol actions in southern Gazala sector
Battle of Bir Hakeim (May 26 - June 11, 1942 - outside Q1 but brigade prepared during Q1)
special_rules: Foreign Legion elite: +1 morale, +1 close combat for 13e DBLE battalions
Isolated position: -1 supply, cannot be easily reinforced
Free French motivation: +1 morale (fighting to liberate France)
Defensive specialists: +1 defensive bonus in prepared positions with minefields
British supply dependency: All supplies come from British Eighth Army logistics
historical_engagements: Syrian Campaign (June-July 1941) - Against Vichy French forces
Battle of Bir Hakeim (May 26 - June 11, 1942 - outside Q1, famous 16-day defense against Rommel's Afrika Korps)

source: War Office document WO216/15 (7 February 1942) - lists Free French Brigade Group under XIII Corps
National WWII Museum: Forgotten Fights - Free French at Bir Hacheim
World History Encyclopedia: Battle of Bir Hakeim
Chemins de mémoire (French Ministry of Defense): Battle of Bir Hakeim
Web search: Pierre Koenig biography, 13e DBLE composition
Web search: Free French Brigade composition 1942
Historical context: Reorganization December 1941, deployment to Bir Hakeim mid-February 1942

chief_of_staff.reason: Free French brigade staff officers not documented in available English-language sources. French military archives likely required.
sources_checked: War Office WO216/15 (lists brigade, not staff)
Web searches for Free French staff officers 1942
chief_of_staff.mitigation: Consult French military archives (Service Historique de la Défense), regimental histories of 13e DBLE

subordinate_commanders.reason: Only Dimitri Amilakvari (13e DBLE commander) identified with confidence from Foreign Legion histories. Other battalion and company commanders not documented in available sources.
subordinate_commanders.mitigation: Consult French Foreign Legion archives, regimental histories, Service Historique de la Défense (SHD)

exact_equipment_counts.reason: Sources confirm 'lacking tanks and much heavy equipment' and 'British-supplied' but don't provide detailed equipment tables. Estimates based on standard British infantry brigade with adjustments for Free French limitations.
sources_checked: Web searches for Free French equipment 1942
exact_equipment_counts.estimate_method: British infantry brigade establishment (~3,700 personnel) used as baseline. Reduced artillery (16 guns vs 24), no tanks (confirmed), limited heavy equipment. Mix of British-supplied (Lee-Enfield, Bren, 25-pounders) and French (MAS-36, 75mm, 47mm AT). Battalion strengths estimated from standard Free French organization.
exact_equipment_counts.mitigation: Consult French military archives (SHD), British supply records for Free French forces, quartermaster returns

battalion_strengths.reason: Sources give brigade total (~3,700-4,000 personnel) but not individual battalion strengths. Distribution estimated from known unit types and standard establishments.
battalion_strengths.estimate_method: Total 3,720 personnel distributed across 11 subordinate units. 13e DBLE (2 battalions) = 900 (largest, Foreign Legion). Other battalions 320-420 each. Support units (artillery, AT, engineers, medical) = 140-280 each. Brigade HQ and services = 235.
battalion_strengths.mitigation: Consult French military archives for unit strength returns, 13e DBLE regimental history, Free French Forces personnel records

notes: Confidence 76% (Tier 2) due to gaps in commanders, exact equipment, and battalion strengths
Command structure confirmed: Pierre Koenig, Général de Brigade from December 1941
Reorganization confirmed: 1st Light Free French Division → 1st Free French Brigade Group December 1941
Deployment confirmed: Moved to Bir Hakeim mid-February 1942 (War Office document, multiple sources)
Composition confirmed: 13e DBLE (2 Foreign Legion battalions), Pacific Battalion, Marine Battalion, Colonial battalions, North African company
Equipment status confirmed: 'Lacking tanks and much heavy equipment', British-supplied logistics
Role confirmed: Anchor southern flank of Gazala Line at isolated Bir Hakeim position
Multinational composition: French metropolitans, Foreign Legion (international), Pacific Marines, African colonials
Notable: Would famously defend Bir Hakeim May 26 - June 11, 1942 (outside Q1) against Rommel's Afrika Korps
Limited English-language sources for Free French brigade details - French archives required for complete data
End Q1 status: Defensive positions at Bir Hakeim, preparing fortifications and minefields, awaiting Axis offensive
